com.pwnetics.helper
Class ItemCounter<K>

java.lang.Object
  com.pwnetics.helper.ItemCounter<K>
Type Parameters:
K - the type of object being counted
public class ItemCounter<K>
extends java.lang.Object

Use this to count objects and calculate simple statistics.

To count objects, consider using increment(Object); this will automatically increment the count associated with the given object. To query the count for an object, consider using get(Object); this will return the count associated with the given object. For objects that have not been added to an ItemCounter, the reported count is always zero.

An object's count will change when the object's count is set(Object, int), or when an object is passed to the increment(Object) method such that the new object is equals() to the object already contained in the ItemCounter. Counts are always non-negative.

Author:
romanows

min

public ItemCounter.KeyValuePair min()
Returns the key/value pair with the lowest value (and secondarily with the "lowest" key). Not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return multiple answers.

Returns:
key/value pair with the lowest value, or if the counter is empty

max

public ItemCounter.KeyValuePair max()
Returns the key/value pair with the largest value (and secondarily with the "largest" key). Not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return multiple answers.

Returns:
key/value pair with the lowest value, or if the counter is empty

mean

public double mean()
Get the mean of all item counts in this collection.

Returns:
the mean of all item counts, or zero if empty.

variance

public double variance()
Get the sample variance of all item counts in this collection. Use this variance if you desire an estimate of the variance of some population of items, of which the current ItemCounter contains only an incomplete sample. Otherwise, see variancePopulation().

Returns:
the sample variance of all item counts, or zero if empty.

variancePopulation

public double variancePopulation()
Get the population variance of all item counts in this collection. Use this variance if you desire to know only the variance of the items in this ItemCounter, otherwise see variance().

There is little difference between the sample and population variance when there are many distinct items. When there are few items, the difference is pronounced. In general, it is probably better to use the sample variance variance().

Returns:
the population variance of all item counts, or zero if empty.

sortByValueKey

public java.util.List<ItemCounter.KeyValuePair> sortByValueKey(boolean isAscending)
Returns a list of key-value pairs that is sorted first by item counts, then by item comparisons if those objects implement Comparable. The returned list is not backed by the item counter, so consider it a snapshot of the item counts.

This sort is not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return various orderings.

Parameters:
isAscending - if true, will sort keys in ascending value; if false, will sort keys in descending value
Returns:
an unmodifiable sorted list

asUnmodifiable

public ItemCounter<K> asUnmodifiable()
Get a view of this as an unmodifiable object. Methods increment(Object) and set(Object, int) will throw UnsupportedOperationException if called. Note that the returned object is just a view of this modifiable ItemCounter, so it can change if the original item counter is changed.

Returns:
an unmodifiable version of this object
